titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Intending to leave the City next Monday for a visit of about two Months to Quincy, I propose intermitting my morning rides on horseback until that time— Captain Conner came to renew his solicitation for employment— His hopes had fixed upon the work for removing the Bar at the mouth of Merrimack river; and he has great confidence in certain mechanical inventions of his own. But neither the Secretary of the Navy nor the Chief Engineer thinks that he can be employed to advantage— They alledge his age and inefficiency as insuperable objections— Major Hoops— Ecce iterum Crispinus—intent upon the great reform in the establishment of Military Store-keepers, and the indispensable necessity of allowing each of them a Clerk—but he is now here to receive his part of the provision made by the Act of the last Session of Congress, for the relief of certain Officers and Soldiers of the Revolutionary War— Mr Rush brought again the Accounts of C. J. Ingersoll and Josiah Randall, for services as Counsel in the suits at Philadelphia, before the U.S. Circuit Court, relating to Edward Thomson’s failure and frauds. He proposed a definitive allowance to each of them, to which I agreed— Genl. Porter brought a Letter from General Scott declaring again his refusal to obey an order of General Macomb; insisting upon his being Macomb’s superior Officer, and asking again for a trial by Court Martial. I desired Genl. Porter to notify the other members of the Administration now here to attend a Cabinet Meeting at one to-morrow. Mr Brent brought drafts of answers to the Notes from Baron Krudener and Baron Lederer— The latter came and had a personal interview with me at which he gave me a copy of the full-power which he has received from the Austrian Government to negotiate a Treaty of Commerce with the United States. This has been consequent upon a prior correspondence between him and the Secretary of State— I told him that upon Mr Clay’s return to this City, a full-power would be given him to negotiate with him for a Treaty, and that it would afford me the highest gratification to establish the commercial relations between the United States and the Austrian dominions upon a mutually satisfactory foundation— General Macomb came and introduced Coll. Gratiot who is now at the head of the Engineer Department— Mr Persico introduced to me his brother, who is a teacher of drawing and resides at Philadelphia. I had much conversation with Mr Rush, upon the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, which is in some danger from the collision of local interests between the three Cities of the District, and the imperious claim of the Corporation of Washington that it should pass through the City— They have already agitated the question of transferring their whole subscription—a Million of Dollars, but upon which no instalment has yet been paid— A pro forma sale to an irresponsible broker, which would be equivalent to withdrawing their subscription altogether— I conversed also with General Macomb and Coll. Gratiot concerning the distribution of the Engineer Officers, upon the Surveys for internal improvement. I signed an order for the remission upon payment of all charges of the penalty upon R. E. Orne, Master of the Barque Cavelier of Salem, for an excess of 2. Passengers from Havre to New-York. Mr Graham sent me for signature 652. Land-grants.
2. IV:30. Shower and Tub Baths— Saturday—

Dr Lovell came to speak of the distressed condition of G. B. English, and to urge that I would give him some encouragement to hope that in the event of continued good behaviour and temperance on his part some appointment will hereafter be given him. I told him that I would give Mr English such assurance so far as might be in my power; but it was impossible for me to do any thing for him at this time— William Thomas is a Son of the late judge Joshua Thomas of Plymouth, and being a candidate for the appointment of Collector at that Port, comes here to obtain it by dint of personal solicitation. I had yesterday requested Mr Rush to issue a Commission to Pelham W. Warren in whose favour after full deliberation I had decided— Mr Thomas was here twice, and finding on his first visit that the Commission had not been despatched endeavoured by argument to change my determination— Importunities of this kind are severe tests of Patience and Temper; and Thomas put mine to the trial— The harshness of a direct refusal is always painful, and sturdy Petitioners will persevere even after it is given. Mr Thomas was not to be repulsed by the information that I had before he came—given directions that the Commission should be made out to Mr Warren— I was ultimately obliged to tell him that I saw no sufficient cause for revoking what I had done.— Mr Brent took back the drafts of his provisional answers to Barons Krudener and Lederer, which I approved with a suggestion of some alterations— Mr Pleasonton called respecting the appointment of some Light-House keeper, and Dr Watkins with Letters from Baltimore— The Postmaster General brought a remonstrance received, against the appointment of Maurice Langhorne as Postmaster at Maysville Kentucky— I advised Mr M’lean to suspend for the present the reception of the Bond. Mr Bulfinch called to mention that he proposed making an excursion for his health to the Western part of the State of New-York. Mr Fullerton, his Son and Dr Young of Pennsylvania came as visitors, Mr Ringgold the Marshal to take leave previous to my departure— There was a Cabinet Meeting to determine upon the course to be pursued with regard to General Scott’s Letter— General Porter read the drafts of two Letters to Scott—one short repeating the command that he should obey the commands of General Macomb, and the refusal to try either Macomb or Scott himself by a Court-Martial; the other assigning at some length the reasons upon which I consider Macomb as entitled to the command, and decline submitting the question to the decision of a Court Martial— These were both fully discussed— The Letter containing the argument was satisfactory, but we all agreed that it should be reserved to be used hereafter, perhaps in the form of a Report— The short Letter was approved, with an amendment, leaving out an intimation that in the event of Scott’s continued disobedience I should dismiss him from the army— I thought this unnecessary particularly as it appeared that Scott although professing to disobey Macomb’s Order had really carried it into effect. This fact however was left somewhat uncertain by the ambiguous tenour of his own Letter, and is to be
ascertained by enquiry of Coll. Jones— John Wilson came again upon the subject of his claim, and of his application for office; upon neither of which I was prepared to decide— Edward Wyer came and took leave— He is going to embark at New-York in the Sloop of War Fairfield, with despatches for Commodore Crane and Mr Offley, our Consul at Smyrna— Thomas J. Hellen dined with us.
3. IV:30— Tub and Shower Baths— Sunday—

Heard this morning at St. John’s Church Mr Hawley, from Luke 10.42— “But one thing is needful.” This was the best discourse that I ever heard from him— The one thing needful is the salvation of the immortal Soul— And the arguments of its immortality, and of its responsibility to future retribution are derived from 1. Reason 2. Conscience— 3. Nature. 4. Revelation— A very good division of the subject; and well sustained by a logically connected chain of deductions— After the Morning Service Mr George B. English called upon me, and repeated an application which he had made by Letter for a vacant appointment. I told him that after the painful necessity I had been under of revoking the commission with which I had charged him it was impossible that I should confer upon him any other Office until after an interval of at least several months it shall be ascertained that the same cause no longer operates to exclude him from the public service— He insisted that I had been misinformed and deceived respecting his habits—that he was not intemperate— That having been the other day very unwell, and having been weakened by loss of blood, a very small quantity of Spirit had affected him; but it was an accident which would not happen again; and he could prove by Mr Eakin who had been for several months past a fellow lodger with him in the same house, that his general habits were of sobriety— I then told him that if Mr Eakin would write me a line to that effect, or call upon me and give me the assurance in person, I would give all proper consideration to his testimony— Within half an hour Mr Eakin came, but instead of confirming English’s assurances, spoke only of his own embarasment, at being called upon by him to bear witness to his exemption from habits of intemperance; being at the same time told by him that his subsistence depended upon this testimony— He said it was extremely distressing to him to feel that the bread of a person for whom he had kind feelings should depend upon what he should say, and he scarcely knew what to say— I told him that was enough. There was no necessity that he should bear testimony against Mr English, who probably laboured under the self-delusion, common to many unfortunate persons in the same condition of not knowing their own habits— In the Evening I heard Mr Lathrop, from Matthew 6.9. “Our father which art in Heaven.” A sensible discourse upon the character of the Lord’s prayer, with reference to the relation which it establishes between man and his maker, corresponding to that between a father and his Children— Mr Lothrop is to preach here only one Sunday more.
4. IV:30. Monday. Tub Bath.— Rossburg— Graeff’s

The day till five in the afternoon was occupied with visitors to take leave, and Heads of Departments on business. Mr Smith introduced Mr Constant Freeman. Mr Graham Commissioner of the General Land Office called, respecting the appointment of Assistant Counsel to the U.S. District Attornies in Florida, on the litigated Land-claims— He has written to Mr Joseph M. White; but knows not where the Letter will find him. I spoke to Mr Graham of the application of John Wilson, for an appointment as surveyor to draw the line between the State of Louisiana and the Territory of Arkansas— Graham said there were two objections to Wilson— His intemperance, and his dishonesty— General Porter was twice here. Coll. Jones the Adjutant General brought a private Letter to him from General Scott’s aid de camp, from which it appears that Scott, carried the Order from General Macomb into effect, though professedly refusing disobedience to it— But as Scott’s own Letter to the Secretary of War is ambiguous on this point, General Porter now makes the enquiry of him and repeats the command to Scott to obey all the Orders of General Scott Macomb as Major General of the Army of the United States.— I had some conversation with Mr Southard, on the subject of the vessel to be despatched upon a scientific and exploring expedition to the South Sea, and expressed to him my earnest wish that her departure might be effected before the Meeting of Congress— Mr Rush was unwell confined to his house and wrote me a note of apology for not coming to take my final directions with regard to the business at the Treasury Department during my absence. Mr Brent came, and took them with respect to the Department of State— I left with him some blank signatures to be used when necessary for Proclamations, Remissions of Penalties, and Commissions of Consuls— Taking of him a receipt for the number and kind of blanks left with him, with directions to return me when I come back all the signed Blanks remaining unused, and to keep and give me an account of all those that shall have been disposed of. This has been my constant practice, with respect to signed Blanks of this description— I do the same with regard to Patents and Land-grants, and it should be extended to Mediterranean Passports and Sea-Letters— But they are always signed in blank by the President, and the responsibility of their use rests at the Department of the Treasury— Stabler was a visitor— Lothrop, Lee and Watkins came to take leave upon my departure. Judge Cranch also gave me two Letters for his Sister Greenleaf at Quincy.

We dined at 3. and at five took our departure— Myself on the horse which I purchased of Governor Barbour: my Son John, Mr Nathaniel Frye, with John Kirke in a low open Phaeton imported from New-York, and a pair of Horses from Baltimore— My wife, my Son’s wife and Abigail S. Adams accompanied us in the Carriage as far as the tavern between the two Bridges at Bladensburg. There we parted from them, and we proceeded to Graeff’s tavern at Rossburg, where we arrived at 7. and are to pass the Night—9 Miles from the President’s House— We found lodging here. Mrs Ladd of Alexandria, and a lively boy her Son.
5. IV:30. Tuesday— Ride from Rossburg to Baltimore.

There had been too much baggage packed behind our light Carriage; and we left two of our Trunks to be sent on by one of the Stages to Baltimore— Edward Wyer passed through Rossburg in a Hack from Washington in the Night— We left Rossburg at five A.M. and arrived at Merrill’s tavern at Waterloo 15 Miles. at 8. There breakfasted—rested our horses till half past eleven—and then rode to Baltimore and at 15 minutes past two, alighted at Barnum’s tavern— The morning was cloudy with a succession of light drizzling Showers, by which being on horseback I was not a little annoyed— And having been so long disused to this exercise, the ride of 27 Miles this day, following that of 9 last Evening was very fatiguing— I found myself also somewhat sore from excoration— We dined immediately after our arrival at Baltimore; and from four in the afternoon till near eleven at Night had a continual stream of visitors, almost all Strangers, but who came to shake hands with the President— In the Evening there was a Jackson party popular meeting, in the Square adjoining to Barnum’s house, at which a young man named M’Mahon, a member of the State Legislature, harangued the multitude for about three hours upon the unpardonable sins of the Administration, and the transcendant virtues of Andrew Jackson— He was still speaking when I retired to bed, and I heard his voice like the beating of a mill-clapper, but nothing that he said. The meeting dispersed about eleven at Night. There was a similar Meeting of the friends of the Administration a few Nights since; and there are Ward Meetings or Committee Meetings of both parties, every day of the week— It is so in every part of the Union— A Stranger would think that the People of the United States have no other occupation than electioneering.
6. IV:15. Wednesday.— From Baltimore to Philadelphia—

After a very good Night’s rest I embarked at 5. this Morning in the Steam-boat United States, Captain Edward Trippe, and at half past twelve at Noon arrived at French-town. Among the Passengers were Mr and Mrs Erwin, the Son in Law and Daughter of Mr Clay, with a little daughter three or four years of age, Mr and Mrs Woodyer, and Mr Barton, an Episcopalian Clergyman of Baltimore, with many others unknown to me. On landing at Frenchtown, we proceeded immediately to Newcastle where we arrived at half past three— I rode my horse; and John and Mr Frye with John Kirke in the Carriage. We preceded the Stages, and had the Carriage and horses shipped in the Steam-boat Delaware Captain Jenkins when the Stages arrived with the other Passengers— At seven in the Evening we arrived at Philadelphia— There was a large concourse of People assembled on the wharf who gave three cheers at my landing, and a multitude of whom followed me as I walked from the wharf to Head’s Mansion-House in South third Street— They shouted continually as I went along, and crowded round me so that I had barely room to pass along. With their Shouts occasionally two or three voices among them cried Huzza for Jackson— The throng chiefly of boys came into the yard, and remained there, still shouting after I entered the House; till in a few minutes I went out upon the Porch, and said “Fellow Citizens, I thank you for this kind and friendly reception, and wish you all good Night”—upon which they immediately dispersed. I had then a succession of visitors till near eleven O’Clock; among whom were J. Sergeant, W. Jones the Collector, Josiah Randall, Edward Ingersoll— J. Connell— J. Vaughan,
R. Walsh, and many others. Among them was a Captain Boardman of the army who spoke of having been tried by a Court-Martial, and of whose decision he appeared to be very apprehensive— I told him that their proceedings had not yet been reported to me, and I could say therefore nothing concerning them— When reported to me I should act upon them as my own duties would require, and with a disposition to do full Justice to him—
7. V:15. Thursday— From Philadelphia to New-Brunswick.

We embarked at 8 this morning in the Steam-boat for Trenton where we landed a little before Noon— The Stage passengers landed about seven miles above, where the Stages were in waiting for them. The regular Steam-boat should have left Philadelphia at 6. A.M. when the state of the tide would not have admitted of the passage of the boat over the shallows to reach Trenton— But an accident having happened yesterday to the regular boat of the line; this Boat, leaving at 8 took the passengers of the early line, and after landing them where the Stages were in waiting for them
